item.title: Australia’s Monthly CPI Cools, Cementing July Rate-Cut Case
item.description: A gauge of Australia’s monthly inflation cooled faster than anticipated in May, moving close to the bottom of the Reserve Bank’s 2-3% target and cementing the case for an interest-rate cut as soon as next month.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

item.title: Bank of Thailand Insider, Top State Banker Vie for Governor Role
item.description: Thailand has shortlisted a career central banker and the head of a state-owned lender as finalists to lead the Bank of Thailand, an appointment closely watched by investors for insights into the future direction of monetary policy.
item.dc:creator: Suttinee Yuvejwattana

media:content.media:description: The Bank of Thailand complex in Bangkok.

item.title: Indrawati Signals Alignment with Prabowo, Says Budget on Target
item.description: Indonesia’s finance minister presented a unified front with President Prabowo Subianto, stressing that the government is committed to fiscal discipline while rolling out the new leader’s priority programs.
item.dc:creator: Grace Sihombing, Haslinda Amin

item.title: Czech Central Bank to Hold Rates and May Signal Longer Break
item.description: The Czech central bank will probably halt interest rate cuts again, with investors awaiting clues about the outlook that may signal a longer pause or even the end of monetary easing.
item.dc:creator: Peter Laca

item.title: AIIB’s Outgoing President Stresses Openness to Global Partners
item.description: The Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank remains open to all countries, including the US and Japan, the lender’s outgoing president said, as the Beijing-based institution looks to emphasize its growing global reach.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger, Haslinda Amin

item.title: Powell Says Higher Inflation Outlook Keeping Fed on Hold for Now
item.description: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell had plenty of opportunities Tuesday to tell lawmakers definitively the central bank will cut interest rates soon. He didn’t take any of them.

item.title: China Is Building a ‘Mega-Sized’ Consumer Economy, Premier Says
item.description: Premier Li Qiang has projected confidence that China can turn consumption into a driver for the economy, while also casting his nation as a stabilizing force in a rapidly shifting global trade landscape.

item.title: Most Hawkish BOJ Member Flags Rate Hike Risk as Inflation Gains
item.description: The Bank of Japan’s most hawkish member said it may be necessary to raise interest rates should inflation risks rise even if economic uncertainty lingers.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka

item.title: China’s Lan Laments Decline of Aid in Speech to Development Bank
item.description: China’s Finance Minister Lan Fo’an warned emerging countries are running short of money to spend on cross-border infrastructure, in remarks at a meeting of a multilateral lender based in Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Fran Wang

item.title: Bank of Korea Warns of Housing, Debt Risks as Easing Continues
item.description: Persistent housing price gains, particularly in the Seoul metropolitan area, could accelerate debt accumulation in South Korea and pose risks to financial stability, threatening a financial system that generally held up well in the face of prolonged political turmoil and US tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Heesu Lee

item.title: Japan Protests Fresh Chinese Activity in East China Sea
item.description: Japan filed a complaint with China after detecting new construction activities in the East China Sea, according to a statement released by Japan’s foreign ministry on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Sakura Murakami

media:content.media:description: Photo by Jam Sta Rosa/AFP via Getty Images Photographer: JAM STA ROSA/AFP

item.title: BOJ Record Signals Shared View Inflation Faster Than Expected
item.description: Bank of Japan board members discussed inflation running at a faster pace than expected while they continued to see the need for vigilance over high uncertainties related to US tariffs, according to a summary of opinions from their policy meeting last week.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka

item.title: Fed’s Schmid Supports Wait-and-See Approach, Watching Price Data
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City President Jeff Schmid said the US central bank should wait to see how tariffs and other policies impact the economy before adjusting interest rates.
item.dc:creator: Catarina Saraiva

media:content.media:description: Jeff Schmid, president of the Kansas City Fed

item.title: Chinese Firms Boost Exports to UK as Trump Tariffs Shift Trade
item.description: Chinese companies are ramping up shipments to Britain to levels not seen in years, a possible sign that the Asian factory powerhouse is finding export markets unimpeded by high tariffs like those President Donald Trump has imposed.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees

item.title: Japan Policy Chief Hits Back at US Call for 5% Defense Spending
item.description: Japan should focus on enhancing its defense capabilities, not chasing spending goals, the ruling party’s policy chief said, following Trump administration calls for US allies to target higher military expenditure.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama, Akemi Terukina

media:content.media:description: Itsunori Onodera, newly-appointed defense minister of Japan, arrives at the Prime Minister's official residence in Tokyo, Japan, on Thursday, Aug. 3, 2017. Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is reshuffling his ministers and party officials after a slump in popularity and a humiliating local election defeat. Photographer: Tomohiro Ohsumi/Bloomberg

item.title: Fed’s Barr Says He Expects Tariffs to Boost Inflation
item.description: Federal Reserve Governor Michael Barr said he anticipates tariffs will drive up inflation and expressed support for a wait-and-see approach to interest-rate adjustments.
item.dc:creator: Amara Omeokwe

media:content.media:description: Michael Barr, vice chair for supervision at the US Federal Reserve, speaks during a Senate Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs Committee hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, May 16, 2024. Martin Gruenberg, the embattled head of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., told lawmakers calling for his resignation that he was moving quickly to overhaul the agency's workplace culture after a probe detailed complaints of sexual harassment and discrimination at the agency.

item.title: Paraguay Central Bank Keeps Benchmark Rate Unchanged at 6%
item.description: Paraguay’s central bank kept monetary policy on hold Tuesday, leaving the benchmark rate unchanged at 6%.
item.dc:creator: Ken Parks

media:content.media:description: Motorists navigate traffic in downtown Ciudad del Este, Paraguay, on Saturday, Dec. 2, 2023. Paraguay's central bank accelerated the pace of monetary easing at its last monthly policy meeting, delivering a surprise half-percentage point cut to drop the benchmark interest rate to 7.25%.

item.title: Fed Needs More Clarity on Tariff Impact on Prices, Kashkari Says
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis President Neel Kashkari said the US central bank needs more clarity on how tariffs will impact prices before adjusting policy, even as recent inflation data has been “quite positive.”
item.dc:creator: Catarina Saraiva

media:content.media:description: Neel Kashkari, president and chief executive officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, speaks during the Monetary and Banking Conference 2024 at the Palacio Libertad in Buenos Aires, Argentina, on Monday, Oct. 14, 2024. Kashkari said it appears likely that "further modest reductions" in the central bank's benchmark interest rate will be appropriate in the coming quarters.

item.description: Two senior Bank of England policymakers warned that the labor market is cooling and pay pressures are easing in one of the strongest signs yet that the central bank is on course to cut interest rates again later this summer.

item.title: Powell Says Key Capital Rule Change May Aid Treasuries Market
item.description: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell said Tuesday that potential changes to a key capital buffer should bolster banks’ roles as intermediaries in the US Treasuries market.
item.dc:creator: Katanga Johnson

media:content.media:description: Jerome Powell, chairman of the US Federal Reserve, during a House Financial Services Committee hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Tuesday, June 24, 2025. Powell told lawmakers the central bank is in no rush to lower interest rates as officials wait for more clarity on the economic impact of President Donald Trump’s tariffs.

item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer said he would push ahead with controversial cuts to UK disability benefits despite a sizable rebellion brewing within his own Labour Party that threatens to derail the plan.

item.title: French Government Under Pressure as Pension Talks Stumble
item.description: Negotiations over France’s contentious retirement reform ended in deadlock late Monday, raising pressure on the government as some opposition parties called for a no-confidence vote.

item.description: US consumer confidence unexpectedly declined in June, underscoring lingering anxiety about the potential impacts on the economy and job market from higher US import duties.

item.title: Hungary Holds Rate as Forecast Points to Stagflation Risk
item.description: Hungary’s central bank kept its key interest rate unchanged for a ninth month, with fresh forecasts pointing to persistent inflation and faltering economic growth. The forint gained against the euro.
item.dc:creator: Zoltan Simon, Marton Kasnyik

item.title: Brazil Central Bank Stresses Plan of High Interest Rate for Longer
item.description: Brazil’s central bank hammered home plans to pause its interest rate hiking cycle in anticipation of the effects on above-target inflation, emphasizing that a great part of the impact is still to come.
item.dc:creator: Martha Viotti Beck

item.title: Trump’s Chip Tariff Threat Sparks Pushback From Auto Industry to Tech
item.description: Blowback to President Donald Trump’s idea of tariffs on imported semiconductors is proving to be broad and deep, stretching from auto companies and boat makers to the technology industry and crypto enthusiasts, according to a review of more than 150 public comments on the proposal.

item.title: Canada Inflation Holds at 1.7% in May as Core Pressures Cool
item.description: Canadian consumer prices held steady while core measures eased slightly, likely giving some relief to Bank of Canada policymakers who had raised concerns about hotter underlying inflation prints in recent months.
